sentences.sentence: This was the most pleasant year of all the life I led in this place.
Friday began to talk pretty well, and understand the names of almost everything I needed to talk about.
I began now to have some use for my tongue again, which indeed I had very little use for( 几乎用不着 ) before.
Besides the pleasure of talking to him, his simple honesty appeared to me more and more every day, and I began really to love the man.
On his side I believe he loved me more than it was possible for him ever to love anyone before.
I asked him whether his tribe( 部落 ) usually won in battle.
He smiled, and said, “Yes, yes, we always fight the better”—that is, he meant always get the better in a fight—and so we began the following conversation:
Master—You always the better; how came you to be taken prisoner, then, Friday?
Friday—They run, one, two, three, and me, and make go in the boat. My tribe( 部落 ) have no boat that time.
Master—Well, Friday, and what does your tribe( 部落 ) do with the men they take? Do they carry them away, and eat them as these did?
Friday—Yes, my tribe( 部落 ) eat mans too, eat all up( 吃光 ).
Master—Do they come here?
Friday—Yes, yes, they come here, come other else place.
Master—Have you been here with them?
Friday—Yes, I have been here [points to the northwest side of the island, which, it seems, was their side].
After this conversation I had had with him, I asked him how far it was from our island to the shore, and whether boats were not often lost on the way.
He told me there was no danger, but that there was a current and wind, always one way in the morning, the other in the afternoon.
This I believed to be no more than the tide( 潮水 ) going out or coming in.
But I afterwards( 后来 ) discovered it was caused by the mighty river Orinoco, and that the land was the great island Trinidad, which sits at the mouth of the river.
I asked if he could tell me how I might leave this island, and meet some white men.
He told me, “Yes, yes, you may go in two boat.”
I could not understand what he meant by two boat, till at last I realized he meant that it must be in a large boat, as big as two boats.
I began to enjoy Friday’s conversation very much.
From this time I began to hope that I might escape from this place, and that this poor native might be a means to help me.
During the long time that Friday had now been with me, and that he began to speak to me, I tried to lay a foundation of religious knowledge in his mind.
I began to teach him about the true God.
I taught him that God was all-powerful, and could do everything for us, give everything to us, and take everything from us.
He listened with great attention, and received with pleasure the idea of Jesus Christ( 耶稣基督 ) being sent to save us.
I entered into a long conversation with him upon the subject of how Jesus( 耶稣 ) could save us all.
I did my best to teach him about these things, but my own knowledge was very limited.
With time, this native became a good Christian, a much better one than I.
As Friday and I got to know each other better, I taught him how to shoot.
I also began to teach him my own history, and described to him the country of England.
I showed him the ruins of the boat I had seen, after seeing which Friday thought for a long time.
I asked him what it was he thought about.
At last, he said, “Me see such boat like come to place at my tribe( 部落 ).”
I understood from him that a similar looking boat had come to the country where he lived, driven there by bad weather.
I presently imagined that some European ship must have been cast away upon their coast.
Friday described the boat to me well enough, but then added with some feeling, “We save the white mans from drowning( 淹死 ).”
Then I asked if there were any white mans, as he called them, in the boat.
“Yes,” he said, “the boat full of white mans.”
I asked him, how many. He told upon his fingers seventeen.
I asked him then what became of them. He told me, “They live with my tribe( 部落 ).”
From this time, I decided to see if I could possibly join with those white men, who I was sure were Spanish or Portuguese( 葡萄牙人 ).
There was no doubt we could find some way to escape together.
So, after some days, I told Friday I would give him a boat to go back to his own tribe( 部落 ).
Friday told me he could help make a boat, and we would travel together, and carry “much enough food, drink, bread”—this was his way of talking.
It was now the twenty-seventh year of my being trapped in this place.
I kept the anniversary( 周年纪念日 ) of my landing here, with the same thankfulness to God as before.
I called to Friday, and told him to go to the seashore( 海岸 ) and see if he could find a turtle or a tortoise( 乌龟 ) to cook.
Friday had not been long gone when he came running back, and before I had time to speak to him he cried out to me, “Oh, master! Oh, master! Oh, sorrow! Oh, bad!”
“What’s the matter, Friday?” said I.
“Over there,” said he, “one, two, three boat!”
“Well, Friday,” said I, “do not be frightened.” So I comforted him as well as I could.
“But, Friday, we must fight them: can you fight, Friday?”
“Me shoot,” said he, “but there come many great number.”
“Do not worry,” said I again, “our guns will scare those that we do not kill.”
So I asked him, whether he would defend me, and do just as I told him.
He said, “Me die when you say die, master.”
Then I took six guns, and loaded them with five small bullets( 子弹 ) each.
I hung my great sword by my side, and gave Friday an axe( 斧头 ).
When I had thus prepared myself, I went up to the side of the hill.
I found quickly that there were about twenty natives, three prisoners, and three boats.
They seemed to be planning to eat these three human prisoners.
I observed also that they had landed, not where they had done when Friday made his escape, but where a thick forest came almost down to the sea.

question.cn: 星期五的部落吃人肉吗？
question.en: Did the people in Friday's tribe eat human flesh?

analysis: 文中说：“Master—Well, Friday, and what does your tribe do with the men they take? Do they carry them away, and eat them as these did? Friday—Yes, my tribe eat mans too, eat all up. ”所以选A 。

question.cn: Robinson怎么看待他的仆人星期五？
question.en: What did Robinson think of his servant Friday?

options.en: He was an honest man and Robinson loved him.
He was wild and had a bad temper.
He was ignorant and couldn't communicate with Robinson.

analysis: 文中说：“Besides the pleasure of talking to him, his simple honesty appeared to me more and more every day, and I began really to love the man.”因此选A。

question.cn: 他们更了解对方后，Robinson教星期五做了什么？
question.en: What did Robinson teach Friday to do after they knew each other better?

options.en: He taught him to make clothes.

analysis: 文中说：“As Friday and I got to know each other better, I taught him how to shoot.” 所以选C。

question.cn: Robinson为什么想去星期五的部落？
question.en: Why did Robinson want to go to Friday’s tribe?

options.cn: 因为他在岛上太寂寞了。
options.en: Because he was so lonely on the island.

options.cn: 因为他想和住在部落的白人一起离开。
options.en: Because he wanted to escape with the white people there.
Because he wanted to attack the tribe.

analysis: 文中说：“There was no doubt we could find some way to escape together. So, after some days, I told Friday I would give him a boat to go back to his own tribe. ”所以选B。

question.en: What was taken to the island by the natives?

analysis: 文中说：“I found quickly that there were about twenty natives, three prisoners, and three boats.”所以选A。
